item.title: Not much of a flatterer! Chrissy Teigen says her one-year-old daughter Luna called her pregnant belly 'YUCKY' while they were in the tub together
item.description: The 32-year-old model said that she and her one-year-old daughter Luna take baths together every night. Recently, Luna pointed at Chrissy's belly and said 'Mama yucky.'
item.content:encoded:
Kids aren't known for their tact, and Chrissy Teigen's one-year-old daughter is no exception. 

The 32-year-old, who is six months pregnant, told E! News that she was recently taking a bath with her little girl Luna, when the toddler voiced some unflattering opinions about her mom's baby bump. 

While the two were bathing, Luna looked at her mother's belly and said bluntly, 'Mama yucky.' 

Scroll down for video 

Aw! Chrissy Teigen said her daughter Luna called her pregnant belly 'yucky' 

Chill mom: Luckily, Chrissy seemed to have a sense of humor about the whole thing 

Growing family: She is pregnant with her second child with husband John Legend 

In the interview Chrissy, laughs as she gushed about how sweet baby Luna is, and how much the little girl loves animals — which shows how 'nurturing and loving she is.' 

Despite the fact that she's loving, she is also very honest, and Chrissy laughed when she shared a recent comment from the adorable tot.

'We take baths together every night and she could say some hurtful things in the bathtub sometimes,' she said. 'Yesterday she pointed at me and was like "mama yucky" and I'm like, "I know. Mama feels kind of yucky."' 

Chrissy didn't take any offense to what Luna said, admitting, 'They're honest, though, these kids, they're honest.'

The proud mom also shared how Luna is gearing up for her soon-to-be baby brother, who arrives in June. The little girl has been feeding her baby dolls with bottles and giving them pats on the back, which Chrissy says is 'so cute to see.'

Most people can attest the fact that at just one glance Luna looks exactly like her father John Legend, 39. However, Chrissy admitted there's more than meets the eye aside from the fact that she said Luna is 'physically a perfect blend of John and I.'

'She has John's big dark eyes, my little mouth and my nose,' she continued.

Real nice: Chrissy said she and Luna take baths together, but the toddler had a special dose of honesty during their recent bathing session 

Uh-oh: Luna is soon getting a little brother, and Chrissy acknowledged that her first born doesn't like to share

Hilarious: The 32-year-old, who is six months pregnant spoke with E! News, about her pregnancy and how Luna is dealing with it

One trait she did inherit from her mother, though, is her attitude — and Chrissy said she is a lot like her, 'which is so funny to see because we shoot each other the same little looks.'

Although Chrissy said she's not worried about how her kids will behave with each other, she did say the one thing she's a little nervous about is sharing.

'I can see Luna...she doesn't exactly love to share until she's totally finished with something. I do hear that the first born tends to be excited for the new addition for maybe a day or so,' she said.

'They don't really realize that they come back day after day after day. So when she starts realizing that he's gonna stick around...maybe things will change,' she continued.

She's not worried about that, though, because she grew up with a sister around. 

Being pregnant is not a burden to Chrissy in the slightest, and she even confessed, 'I really am a happy pregnant person.

'I feel like I'm kind of quiet about that because everyone has a different kind of pregnancy and it could be exhausting at times but I will say I really love being pregnant.'

Traits: One trait Luna inherited from her mom is her attitude

Same personality: She said it's funny that Luna has the same personality as her because they shoot each other 'the same little looks'

Happy: Being pregnant is not a burden to Chrissy, and she even confessed, 'I really am a happy pregnant person

'I appreciate the style that comes with it and I like the belly rubbing,' she joked about loving pregnancy. 

As for what's different this time around she admitted her worries are totally different.

'With Luna everything is new and you worry about things like am I sleeping wrong and is this bad to eat. Even with this baby boy I'm still worried about Luna — is she jealous, is she going to be mad at me when he comes out?

'It's a different type of worry but I feel like I got this down and I'm definitely not worried about him I know were good.' 

Sharing how excited she is to have two babies running around the house Chrissy gushed that 'two in pampers is going to be hysterical it's going to be a wild ride.

'We love the chaos around our house. There's an open door policy and everyone's in and out all the time and I like that.

'I like the idea that I'm going to have two little tushes running around and pushing on each other and playing with the dogs. I love that,' she concluded.
item.dc:abstract: Chrissy, 32, is currently six months pregnant with a baby boy. The child, her second with 39-year-old husband John Legend, is due in June. The model said that she and her one-year-old daughter Luna take baths together every night. Recently, Luna pointed at Chrissy's belly and said 'Mama yucky.' Chrissy, who is known to laugh at herself, indicated that she thought the incident was funny.
item.dc:creator: Carly Stern
item.mi:shortTitle: Chrissy Teigen reveals her daughter called her pregnancy bump 'yucky'

item.title: Bust a move! Man who traveled around the world for two years asking strangers to dance for him shows off the results in an uplifting video
item.description: Miklas Manneke, from Johannesburg, South Africa, began his 'passion project' more than two years ago, while traveling in China, and continued the initiative in a wide range of countries.
item.content:encoded:
A filmmaker who traveled around the world asking people to dance for him has compiled the result of his work in a touching video.

Miklas Manneke, from Johannesburg, South Africa, began his 'passion project' more than two years ago, while traveling in China.

There, he began asking strangers to bust a move in front of his lens—and ended up continuing the initiative while visiting a wide range of countries including France, the US, Belgium, China, and Germany.

Scroll down for video 

Challenge: Filmmaker Miklas Manneke traveled around the world asking people to dance for him and has compiled the result of his work in a touching video (pictured)

Idea: The filmmaker, from Johannesburg, South Africa, began his 'passion project' more than two years ago, while traveling in China and ended up continuing the initiative

In order to shoot his video, Manneke only used iPhones, and he went through four different generations of the item over the course of the project.

His two-minute clip shows some people were initially reticent to dance for him, with one man even telling him: 'No I don't want to.'

But plenty of strangers were willing to participate, eventually warming up to the idea.

The video shows them confidently busting their best moves in a variety of settings, be it on a New York City subway platform or in front of a restaurant in Paris.

Gear: In order to shoot his video, Manneke only used iPhones, and he went through four different generations of the item over the course of the project

Reactions: Some people were reluctant to dance for him at first and eventually let lose, while others didn't hesitate to bust a move, be it with skis on, or in a moving bus

Circumstances: People can be seen dancing in a variety of settings, including this man who shimmied on a boat

One person even managed to dance with skis on their feet, while holding onto their poles, while someone else shimmied inside a moving bus. 

Through the video, Manneke wanted to show that movement can united people regardless of where they are from, the language they speak, or their culture. 

'The world is in a place right now where there are so many things dividing us, be it boarders, languages or culture,' he told the blogger Chris Jones.

'There was something special about sharing that moment with people around the world when they danced. Something that transcended geography.'

Asking strangers to dance in front of his phone camera could have been nerve-wracking, but Manneke came out of the experiment convinced that approaching others doesn't have to be frightening. 

Message: Through the video, Manneke wanted to show that movement can united people regardless of where they are from, the language they speak, or their culture

Connection: Asking strangers to dance in front of his phone camera could have been nerve-wracking, but Manneke believes approaching others doesn't have to be frightening

Effect: Manneke has so far racked up 2,960 views on his clip on YouTube, with people praising his work in the comments section and saying it lifted their spirits

'The biggest lesson was that you shouldn't be scared to ask,' he said. 'It was about putting myself in the position where you have to approach people and ask them to dance.'

Manneke, who ended his video with the hashtag #keepdancing, has so far racked up 2,960 views on his clip on YouTube, with people praising his work in the comments section.

'This makes me so happy right now,' one person said about the video. 'You're amazing!'

Another viewer said the video has managed to lift their spirits, writing: 'This just makes me smile.'
item.dc:abstract: Miklas Manneke, from Johannesburg, South Africa, began his 'passion project' more than two years ago, while traveling in China. There, he began asking strangers to bust a move in front of his lens—and ended up continuing the initiative while visiting a wide range of countries including France, the US, Belgium, China, and Germany. In order to shoot his video, Manneke only used iPhones, and he went through four different generations of the item over the course of the project. His two-minute clip shows some people were initially reticent to dance for him, with one man even telling him: 'No I don't want to.' But plenty of strangers were willing to participate, eventually warming up to the idea.

item.title: 'They told me I'd been butchered': Mum-of-four left with lopsided, mismatched breasts after Australian surgeon botched her boob job so badly she started leaking silicone
item.description: A Gold Coast-based mum-of-four has opened up on the horrors of her failed boob job. She said she said she didn't research extensively and thought because her doctor was Australian, she was safe.
item.content:encoded:
A mother-of-four has revealed how her boob job, which was done by an Australian doctor, left her with a serious infection and lopsided breasts.

Samantha Humm from the Gold Coast said she dreamed of having breast implants since she was 19, and that she jumped at the chance after seeing an ad on Facebook offering affordable surgery.

The 30-year-old told 9Honey she didn't want to have the procedure overseas because she had heard that the doctors 'could be dodgy.'

Gold Coast-based Samantha Humm (pictured) said she jumped at the chance to have surgery after seen an ad online

She said she attended a consultation, chose a breast size, signed paperwork and booked in for the procedure. 

Ms Humm said she didn't research her choice of surgeons extensively because she thought she would be covered by regulation as her doctor was based in Australia.

Her operation was carried out in 2015, and the Gold Coast mum said at first everything seemed fine.

'They were healing really well. I wasn't in much pain and they looked really good.'

However, two weeks into her recovery Ms Humm said she noticed her left breast had reddened and she had started to feel pain.

Two weeks after her surgery, Ms Humm said she notice her left breast had started to become red and was feeling pain

She said she didn't think too much of these changes at first and put them down to being part of the healing process.

It wasn't until she had a shower and was drying herself that she noticed how much her left breast had swelled, and there was now fluid seeping out of a wound.

She made a call to her cosmetic surgeon to alert him to the situation, but because it was a Friday she claims he told her he wouldn't be able to see her until the following Monday.

Samantha Humm (right) said although her left breast was leaking fluid her doctor assured her this was part of the healing process

At her appointment, her doctor took a swab and assured her it was part of the healing process.

But Ms Humm said her breast continued to swell, was painful and was still leaking fluid - so much so she had to wear pads in her bra.

She said she became very concerned about the state of her breast after it turned black, and that she had started 'freaking out' because now silicone was coming out of it too.

Doctors at Ms Humm's local hospital were horrified by her breast job, telling her they had never seen anything like it 

'I was actually pulling it out with my fingers out of my breast,' she revealed.

She said she sent her doctor a photo to show him how bad things had become and that he had told her to come into his rooms the following week.

Instead, Ms Humm said she went to her local hospital who told her they'd never seen anything like it - telling her she looked like she been 'butchered' and that her doctor had done 'a horrible job.'

On the hospital's recommendation, she returned to her original doctor and had her left implant removed at a further cost of $2,000.

On the hospital's recommendation, Ms Humm (left) returned to her original doctor and had her left implant removed at a further cost of $2,000 

Her left breast developed another infection, and while this eventually healed, she was told she would need to pay a further $2,000 to have the implant put back in.

She said she made the decision not to do this and was left with a saggy breast with nothing in it, and one with an implant that 'was a horrible job.'

The mother-of-four had the right implant removed just three weeks ago, after years of living with mismatched, lopsided breasts.

While Ms Humm has since made contact with other dissatisfied patients of the same doctor through Facebook, she wasn't aware previously there had been multiple complaints made.

In September 2017, Jean Huang, 35, died after an allegedly botched cosmetic procedure at a salon in NSW

Although it's not known whether Ms Humm's surgeon was practising without adequate qualifications - this is an issue those in the industry say is a serious problem. 

As a result women are suffering disfigurement, depression and, in some rarer, cases death.

Last year, Jean Huang, 35, died after an allegedly botched cosmetic procedure at a salon in NSW.

In 2008, 28-year-old Lauren Edgar from Adelaide died from a bacterial infection resulting from a liposuction procedure.

Cosmetic procedure checklist: 

1. Try to find someone you know, who has had the procedure, to give a first hand account. Then find out which doctor performed the treatment

2. Make an appointment with the doctor at a time when you're not rushed. Arrive on time, observe the clinic – is it clean, well structured and well run? It's important to take into account the cleanliness and presentation of the practice, as it can be an indication of the overall level of care provided

3. Make sure you find out what impact the procedure will have on your lifestyle and assess if you can manage that. Ensure costings have been explained. If something is temporary, find out how long will it last and when it may need repeating

4. For more major procedures, always go home and think about your decision. If you do decide to proceed with the treatment, make sure you allow for any downtime that may result from the procedure 

5. Plan on having at least two opinions before proceeding with any treatment. Any consultation should be face to face, not over Skype with a remote doctor unless you live in a remote rural area 

Source: Cosmetic Physicians College of Australasia

And in 2007,  Melbourne-based Lauren James, died after complications from liposuction on her legs and buttocks.

According to Associate Professor Gazi Hussain, the Vice President of the Australian Society of Plastic Surgeons, the industry isn't properly regulated and this is leading to significant issues across Australia.

'We've really seen this increasing number of practitioners who are not trained in surgery, let alone in plastic surgery who are undertaking procedures, and it is primarily because the area is unregulated.'
item.dc:abstract: A Gold Coast-based mother-of-four has spoken out about how a failed boob job left her with a serious infection and with disfigured and lopsided breasts (top and bottom right). Samantha Humm (left) revealed how she had been dreaming of having breast implants since she was 19, and that she jumped at the chance after seeing an ad offering affordable surgery online. She said she didn't research her choice thoroughly as she should have because she thought she would be covered by regulation as her doctor was based in Australia: 'I never wanted to get them done overseas because I’d heard they could be dodgy.' Just two weeks after her procedure, her breasts started to go red, leak fluid and she was in pain.
item.dc:creator: Sheree Mutton
item.mi:shortTitle: Mum reveals how a badly botch boob job left her with disfigured body

item.title: How to pick the perfect Airbnb home: Couple who have stayed in 178 properties reveal their top 6 visits - and why you should always use the PEARL method when choosing a place
item.description: Debbie, 62, and Michael Campbell, 72, who sold all of their worldly possessions in 2013 and set off on 'one last trip' around the world together are in Sydney sharing their Airbnb tips.
item.content:encoded:
Airbnb is quickly becoming one of the best ways for travellers to feel like they're 'living' in a country - rather than just passing through.

A couple who would agree with that sentiment is Debbie, 62, and Michael Campbell, 72, who sold all of their worldly possessions in 2013 and set off from Seattle on 'one last trip' around the world together.

They've visited an incredible 70 countries and stayed in 178 Airbnb listings - even being asked by the company to head to HQ and complete a 10-week internship - and they've shared some of their best accommodation tips with FEMAIL.

They've visited an incredible 68 countries and stayed in 148 Airbnb listings (pictured)

'We use the PEARL method to decipher whether an Airbnb is right for us and fits into the budget,' Debbie said.

'So first of all you need to obviously look at the price. We always recommend sticking to your limits and saving even more money by purchasing groceries and cooking in the home you select,' she continued.

The 'Senior Nomads' - who will celebrate their 40th wedding anniversary this year - usually choose the 'entire apartment or home' selection on the website, rather than just a private room, but it depends on how much time you're spending there.

Juan Carlos' well decorated loft in Mexico City, Mexico, is a firm favourite with travellers

A couple who would agree with that sentiment is Debbie, 62, and Michael Campbell, 72, who sold all of their worldly possessions in 2013 and set off on 'one last trip' (pictured)

'If it's a short stay occasionally we'll just book a one room place,' Michael said

'If it's a short stay occasionally we'll just book a one room place,' Michael said.

'E stands for expectation. What do you expect from your place? Make sure you really look at the pictures the home owner is supplying you with and decide if it's going to give you the best experience,' Debbie said.

As part of the PEARL system A stands for amenities.

Some of the best Airbnb homes they recommend travellers 

Source: Senior Nomads 

The couple - who will celebrate their 40th wedding anniversary this year - usually choose the 'entire apartment or home' selection on the website

'We encourage people to decide what's important to them. So for us it's wifi, a decent sized kitchen, a big table (for our laptops and to do jigsaw puzzles on) and sometimes a little outdoor space,' Debbie continued

The travelling PEARL method

P stands for price: Stick to your budget and set yourself a limit.

E stands for expectation: What do you expect from your host or the accommodation?

A stands for amenities: Do you want a large kitchen, big bed or a pool in the home? Decide what's important.

R stands for reviews: Suss out what other people are saying on the listing - the are often hidden gems of information there.

L stands for location: Are you in the centre of town or are you going to require public transport?

'We encourage people to decide what's important to them. So for us it's wifi, a decent sized kitchen, a big table (for our laptops and to do jigsaw puzzles on) and sometimes a little outdoor space,' Debbie continued.

If you're after a pool or a pool table, decide early on what you can and can't live without in a space and then double check each listing has it.

'R is for Reviews as part of that method. Often some of the best pieces of advice come from the reviews - we write one every time we leave a place,' Michael said.

Whether it's how close or far away the listing is from the city centre or how big the space really is, a lot of those extra details are revealed through the review system. 

If you're after a pool or a pool table, decide early on what you can and can't live without in a space and then double check each listing has it (Debbie and Michael pictured)

Whether it's how close or far away the listing is from the city centre or how big the space really is, a lot of those extra details are revealed through the review system

Which leads us to the last point - location.

'If you want a quiet little place by the beach then you're not going to want to read about lots of noise surrounding a listing!' Michael said.

'We don't have a car so things need to be accessible by either walking or public transport - so that's an important factor to consider.

'If you want a quiet little place by the beach then you're not going to want to read about lots of noise surrounding a listing!' Michael said

'I love finding local groceries and markets in each country and I'm a keen cook,' Debbie said

The couple usually book their place three or four weeks in advance - although sometimes closer to the departure time out of 'laziness' - but insist they save money by cooking at home.

'I love finding local groceries and markets in each country and I'm a keen cook,' Debbie said.

They also complete a free walking tour, which tends to last upwards of three hours, in every city.

They also complete a free walking tour, which tends to last upwards of three hours, in every city

'So for instance we're in Sydney right now and there are two we found online. The guides work off tips so they're usually really enthusiastic,' Debbie said.

As for how much longer they will live life on the roads, that's the only thing they don't have a steadfast plan for.

'We decided early on we'd keep doing it as long as we're healthy, having fun and staying close to budget, and we're still in love,' Michael said.

You can follow the Senior Nomads journey on their website.
item.dc:abstract: Debbie, 62, and Michael Campbell, 72, who sold all of their worldly possessions in 2013 and set off on 'one last trip' around the world together are in Sydney sharing their Airbnb tips. They've visited an incredible 70 countries and stayed in 178 listings (some are pictured here). 'We use the PEARL method to decipher whether an Airbnb is right for us and fits into the budget,' Debbie said. This means they consider the price, expectation, amenities, reviews and location every time they select a home.

item.title: Why DO kings trump queens in a deck of cards? Fascinating social experiment challenges outdated rules which 'blindly teach children that boys are better than girls'
item.description: In the 60-second film from FCB Inferno, a group of young girls play a simple game of 'highest card wins' against an adult - and take their opponents to task on the outdated rules.
item.content:encoded:
A fascinating social experiment has set out to challenge a group of adults on why the king outranks the queen in a traditional pack of playing cards.

In the 60-second film, five young girls aged between seven and 11 play a simple game of 'highest card wins' against an adult - and take their opponents to task on the outdated rules.

Traditionally, a king or an ace is the highest-ranking card in a standard 52-card deck.

But one man tells his young opponent that his king trumps her queen - and he is therefore the winner - she asks him to explain why.

Each of the adult participants is stumped when asked to explain why those were the rules, with one saying: 'A king outranks a queen.' 

Others are left scratching their heads, with one woman admitting: 'I don't know.'

One of the little girls hits back, saying: 'Just because they're a different gender doesn't mean that the king should win.'

After much pressing from the little girls, each player agrees to change the rules so that the queen would trump the king instead.

Filmed by FCB Inferno - the agency behind This Girl Can - the film is part of a campaign called #QueenRules and aims to 'raise important questions about what we subconsciously teach children about gender'.

The experiment set out to see how adults would deal with 'gender bias': Would they blindly teach children that boys are better than girls, or would they change the rules?

'Why?' In the 60-second film, a group of young girls play a simple game of 'highest card wins' against an adult - and take their opponents to task on the outdated rules

Each of the adult participants find themselves stumped when asked to explain why those were the rules, with one saying: 'A king outranks a queen'

Inspired by a real conversation with a five-year-old girl about why kings were 'better' than queens in a standard 52-card deck, producers asked each adult to teach a small girl a simple card game.

The short video was produced by Archer's Mark and directed by Libby Burke Wilde, with producer Jo-Jo Ellison ensuring each department was made up of women – from the cinematographer to the colourist.

The #QueenRules project launched on International Women's Day and hopes to encourage a new way to play cards where the queen outranks the king.

When one man (pictured) tells his young opponent that his king trumps her queen - and he is therefore the winner - she challenges him to explain why

Important cause: The #QueenRules project launched on International Women's Day and hopes to encourage a new way to play cards where the queen outranks the king

Simultaneous live events and poker tournaments took place around the world to mark the official launch of the new rules, using limited edition decks of cards illustrated by female artists.  

The agency said it hopes to challenging people to change how they think and play with the new rules.

FCB Global's CCO Susan Credle said: 'A father is asked by his five-year-old daughter why the king is a better card than the queen. 

'And this campaign was his answer. Unconscious bias slowly, subtlety shapes who we become. Listening to how someone else views the world empowers us all.'

For examples of how to play, and which games work with Queen Rules, visit queenrulesproject.com
item.dc:abstract: In the 60-second film from FCB Inferno, a group of young girls play a simple game of 'highest card wins' against an adult - and take their opponents to task on the outdated rules. Each of the adult participants is stumped when asked to explain why those were the rules, with one simply saying: 'A king outranks a queen.' Others are left scratching their heads, with one woman admitting: 'I don't know.'

item.mi:shortTitle: Why DO kings trump queens in a pack of cards?

item.title: Stunning student, 20, from Wales is tipped to be Bollywood's next leading lady after catching the eye of a top Indian director
item.description: Unknown in the UK, English student Banita Sandhu, 20, from Caerleon in Newport, Wales, could be the next big thing in Bollywood, after being spotted by a top director.
item.content:encoded:
A 20-year-old has been plucked from the Welsh valleys to become a shining star in Bollywood. 

Banita Sandhu, from Caerleon in Newport, has landed the lead in a new Indian film after being spotted by one of the industry's star directors. 

Sandhu, a second-generation Indian, was cast in new movie October after she starred in an advert for Wrigley's chewing gum, which was watched by nearly 40million people.  

Scroll down for video

From the Welsh valleys to Dehli: Banita Sandhu, 20, is the star of a new Bollywood film after being spotted by high-profile Indian director Shoojit Sircar

Sandhu, a student at King's College London, was whisked to Delhi for nearly 40 days to film the Bollywood movie October (opposite actor Varun Dhawan) - the actress said the experience enabled her to learn more about her grandparent's heritage

Director Shoojit Sircar, who shot the commercial, then mentioned a part in his latest film that he was keen for Sandhu to take. 

In an interview with the BBC, the up-and-coming star said she grew up watching the best of British television, and it inspired her to take up acting. 

She says: 'I used to watch soaps as a child, with the goal of landing a part in Coronation Street. At the age of 10, I sat my mum down and told her my plans.

'Luckily, she took me seriously and found me an agent, but education still came first.'

After a few minor roles during childhood, Sandhu concentrated on landing bigger roles after turning 18 - and didn't have to wait long before filming the commercials saw her face go viral across India. 

A Vodafone advert garnered a million hits in India and led to the Wrigley's ad. 

While studying English Literature at King's College London, the actress got the call she was waiting for and quickly signed up to Hindi lessons.

Bandhu learnt some Hindi to make her accent more authentic but says she plans to finish her degree before taking up acting full-time  

The film sees Bandhu co-star with Varun Dhawan, who is already a huge star in India

Filming October in Delhi was an education in acting but also in her cultural heritage says the rising star.   

She explains: 'My grandparents came to Britain from the Punjab, northern India, shortly after World War Two. 

'Both my parents were born here and my sister and I were raised in a middle-class existence in Caerleon.

'As we had no relatives in India, I had no reason to learn about it or engage with this history. So I loved learning more about the culture and my family's lives, struggles and traditions.'

The film features a group of students studying hotel management and sees her star alongside actor Varun Dhawan, who is hugely popular in India. 

While fame beckons thousands of miles away, Sandhu is unknown here and has vowed to finish her degree before she acts full-time. 

Sandhu's film, October is released worldwide on 13 April

The English student was plucked from obscurity after starring in an advert for Wrigley's chewing gum, which went viral across India. (Pictured from left: Banita Sandhu, starring opposite Varun Dhawan in new film October)

item.title: 'I am 44 years old and my milk is perfect!' Nursing mother shares brutal comeback for strangers who said women her age are 'too old' to breastfeed their children
item.description: Stefani Giraldi, from Italy, had her first baby at 37, and gave birth to her second aged 39. She overheard two women in their thirties saying women in their forties were too old to breastfeed.
item.content:encoded:
A 44-year-old mom-of-two has revealed how she hit back at strangers who told her she was too old to breastfeed.  

Stefani Giraldi had her first baby at the age of 37, and gave birth to her second at age 39. Despite starting her family a bit later in life, the Italian mom is a vocal breastfeeding advocate.

Recently, though, she was forced to address her age and the quality of her milk supply after she overheard two women talking about the dangers of feeding babies 'older' milk. 

Speaking out: Mom-of-two Stefani Giraldi, 44, from Italy, has revealed her reaction to hearing two women say she was too old to breastfeed

Happy family: The mom-of-two has a six-year-old son and three-year-old daughter and is still breastfeeding her youngest 

Taking on her popular Facebook parenting page Mama's Word, she said that after six consecutive years of breastfeeding, she didn't think anything could 'shock' her.

'I am sure you are all familiar with the "too old to breastfeed" remark, BUT have you ever heard it in relation to the MOTHER???' she wrote

'That's right, these two ladies were going on about how a woman they knew, who is 42 years old, was, in their opinion, too OLD to breastfeed!! 

'And how her milk is probably not GOOD enough because of her age, to the disadvantage of the baby. A baby who they though would have been better off formula fed instead,' she shared. 

Explaining that the comments left her 'fuming,' Stefania, who has yet to wean her three-year-old, said she was able to confront their comments head-on after her daughter asked to be fed.

Mature mom: Stefani, who runs the popular parenting Facebook page Mama's Word, had her first baby at 37 and gave birth to her second at age 39

Breast is best? She said that she overheard two women in their thirties saying women in their forties were too old to breastfeed and formula would be better for the baby

'Obviously the ladies noticed I was breastfeeding (I wasn't hiding), I turn to them and I tell them: "By the way, I am 44 years old, 45 next June and my milk is perfect!" The look on their face, priceless,' she added. 

She also detailed that it felt 'good' to stand up to their comments, before asking other mothers what they would have done. 

The post quickly went viral, with dozens of mothers taking to the comments section to voice their support for Stefania. 

Follower Tanya Santin wrote: 'I'll high five that'. 

While Alison Faulkner typed: 'You sock it to them! I had my third child at 44 and breast fed her for 2 and a half years! I was getting letters for breast screening at 45 and had to keep postponing it um sorry I am still breast feeding!!! Bring on the healthy children'. 

Shock factor: Stefani recounted that she then started breastfeeding her three-year-old in front of the women before telling them she was turning 45 on her next birthday

Reaction: Stefani also told them her milk was 'perfect' but was 'fuming' after hearing their comments

A sentiment shared by Vai Das who shared: 'I strongly believe that millions years of evolution can't be wrong. Mammals are most advanced organisms in the world. (Mammals are creatures who breastfeed their cubs.. if you didn't know). There is a lot of research done and proven that breast milk is dynamic and constantly changing. Constantly adopting to child's needs.' 

The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recommends that breastfeeding continue for at least 12 months, and thereafter for as long as mother and baby desire. 

The World Health Organization recommends continued breastfeeding up to two years of age or beyond.
item.dc:abstract: Stefani Giraldi, from Italy, had her first baby at 37, and gave birth to her second aged 39. She overheard two women in their thirties saying women in their forties were too old to breastfeed, and formula would be better for the baby. Taking to her popular Facebook parenting page Mama's Word, Stefani recounted that she then started breastfeeding her three-year-old. She also informed the women she was 45 her next birthday and told them her milk was 'perfect,' but she was 'fuming' after hearing their comments.
item.dc:creator: Carly Stern
item.mi:shortTitle: Mom, 44, hits out at women who said she was too old to breastfeed

item.title: 'Congress needs to know that the people are watching': Activist behind the pink pussyhats reveals why she wanted to make 'evil eye' gloves the symbol of the March for Our Lives
item.description: Krista Suh created the Pussyhat Project ahead of the Women's March in 2017. She said she had a dream about a 'sea of eyes' and tried to make it a reality at Saturday's March for Our lives.
item.content:encoded:
The woman behind the pussyhats made popular at the Women's March in 2017 was back with a new fashion statement for the March for Our Lives on Saturday: evil eye gloves.

Krista Suh, who created the popular Pussyhats Project, switched  things up for this weekend's protest. She wrote on her blog that the idea of a 'sea of eyes' came to her in a dream.

'I had a dream of a protest, a huge peaceful crowd with their hands outstretched toward the sky — each palm had a huge EYE drawn on it,' she wrote. 

Making a stand: Krista Suh, the creator of the pink pussyhats worn during the Women's March, had a new fashion statement for the March for Our Lives

See no evil: Krista encouraged protesters to wear the'evil eye' on their gloves

In good company: Krista pictured with mayor of Washington, D.C. Muriel Bowser and Nancy Pelosi before Saturday's march also wanted the evil eye to show Congress 'eyes are on them' 

'Some of you might know I came up with the idea for the Pussyhat and the Sea of Pink in the car while driving up the 5 freeway on November 12, 2016, just days after Election Day,' she wrote.

'What many people don’t know is that I had an idea, a vision, before that. It came to me in a dream, just minutes before waking up -It was a Sea of Eyes.

'I’ve been hanging on to that image knowing that it was going to do something, mean something. I got invited to the March for Our Lives Facebook page,' she went on. And that’s when I knew. It is time.

'I’m calling on you to help make the Sea of Eyes a reality. To make a statement that enough is enough and gun violence has to stop.' 

Sea of eyes: Krista wanted thousands of marchers to don evil eye gloves to create a 'Sea of Eyes' during the marches around the country

Pledge: By Saturday, Krista had logged 1,528 pairs of pledged gloves on her website

Creating a fundraising page on her blog, Krista said that she wanted to collect a minimum of 438 gloves, to represent the 438 people who have been killed or injured in school shootings since 2014.

However, she also said that she wanted to collect 'thousands more' to 'show Congress just how many pairs of eyes are on them right now — waiting for (demanding!) them to do the right thing.'

By Saturday, Krista had logged 1,528 pairs of pledged gloves on her website, with marchers promising to wear them out for the protest.

Hundreds of protesters then took to social media during the marches to show their support by posting pictures of their gloves in action. 

In many cultures and religions including Judaism, Hinduism, and Buddhism, wearing an evil eye talisman is believed to provide protection against evil forces. 

Action: Hundreds of protesters took to social media during the marches to show their support by posting pictures of their gloves in action

Inclusive: While pussyhats became the de-facto feminist symbol of the Women's March, some felt they were exclusionary — however, the evil eye does not exclude any race or gender

May the force be with you: In many cultures and religions including Judaism, Hinduism, and Buddhism, wearing an evil eye talisman is believed to provide protection against evil forces

In recent years, it has gained popularity — and in 2016, the evil eye appeared on the Alexander McQueen, Givenchy, and Chanel fall runways, bringing the ancient trend into mainstream consciousness.

Taking to Instagram the day after the march, Suh wrote: 'I am still completely in awe and SO proud of everyone who came together yesterday'.  

While the hand-knitted pussyhats became the de-facto feminist symbol of the Women's March in 2017, many transgender women and gender nonbinary people felt the focus on traditional female genitals was exclusionary and offensive.

The focus on pink genitals was seen to exclude women of color also.
item.dc:abstract: Krista Suh created the Pussyhat Project ahead of the Women's March in 2017 and was the reason so many protesters wore the pink hats. She said she had a dream about a 'sea of eyes' and tried to make it a reality at Saturday's March for Our lives. She wanted to collect 438 gloves, to represent the 438 people who have been killed or injured in school shootings since 2014. Hundreds of women have posted pictures of themselves on social media wearing evil eye gloves to the march.
item.dc:creator: Carly Stern
item.mi:shortTitle: Why 'evil eye' gloves became the symbol of the March for Our Lives

item.title: 'This is an important movie, and a really good one': Matt Bomer buys out showing of Love, Simon so fans could see the romantic comedy about a gay teenager for free
item.description: The 40-year-old White Collar star bought out the 4pm screening at a Texas theater on March 25. He wanted people to be able to see the emotional movie about a teenager coming out as gay.
item.content:encoded:
Matt Bomer bought out his hometown theater so that locals could see the movie Love, Simon for free.

The 40-year-old White Collar star, who came out publicly as gay in February 2012, gave theatergoers at Spring 10 Sony Theatre in Spring, Texas this weekend to give young people the opportunity to enjoy the film's powerful message. 

'Simon Halls and I bought out the whole screening for you. This is an important movie, and a really good one,' he wrote on Instagram, announcing the kind gesture.  

Generous: Matt Bomer bought out his hometown theater in Spring, Texas so that people could go see the movie Love, Simon for free

Special: The 40-year-old actor publicly came out as gay in February 2012

Amazing: Tickets were given out for free at the door, and people have taking to Twitter to applaud him for his generosity

Partners: Matt bought out the theater along with his husband Simon Halls, 54

Important: 'Simon Halls and I bought out the whole screening for you. This is an important movie, and a really good one,' he wrote

The movie Love, Simon is about a teenager, Simon Spier, who comes out as gay after high school to his friends and family.

Fans have been applauding the messages of the film and stressing its importance for helping LGBTQ teens.

This weekend, Matt shared on social media that he and his husband Simon Halls, 54, bought out the entire 4 p.m. screening of the movie on March 25, and made tickets available for free at the box office the day of the show. 

'Please come see Love, Simon in my hometown of Spring, TX for free! ' he wrote. 'I know you'll love it so come watch for free this Sunday! #loveislove #hometown #springtx #lovesimon'

After he announced the selfless gesture, fans thanks the star for being so thoughtful. 

Appreciation: People took to Twitter to thank Matt for the gesture

Tickets: This excited movie goer shared the tickets her and her friends got from Matt

Applause: One woman shared how great it is that Matt and his husband are so authentic

Generous: This woman said how generous and caring Matt is

Inspiration: One user wrote what an inspiration Matt is to everyone

'Role model here everyone,' one man wrote, while one woman gushed, 'You are a great man.'

One user commented, 'Great work Matt Bomer, improving accessibility to drive progress for inclusion.'

'What a great way to use your platform! You'll probably never know how many people's lives will be improved by this wonderful gesture,' another woman wrote.

One sweet woman even commented, 'What a great gift! Thank you so much. Those young people and all people from your hometown are truly blessed.'

Meanwhile, another woman sent Matt a heartfelt message writing, 'God bless you and Simon. I'm sure the 14-year-old you is feeling very proud and happy right about now. 

'It may not have seemed so back then, but here you are living your Happy Ever After and other LGBTQ kids can see that not only does it get better, dreams really do come true.' 

Dreams: User Andrea shared how proud 14-year-old Matt would be of himself today

Love: This woman shared that what Matt did is just another reason why she loves him

Movie: Another person tweeted that the movie was amazing and should be seen by everyone

Blessed: One man John, shared that all people from Spring are so blessed

Several other celebrities have rented out movie theaters so that people could see the film as well, including Kristen Bell and Neil Patrick Harris.

Kristen, 37, bought a screening of the film in her hometown of Minneapolis and shared an Instagram raving about the film.

'Love, Simon is a KNOCKOUT. There are so many important stories that don't get made,' she wrote. 'I am so grateful this one did.'

'I had absolutely nothing to do with the making of this movie. I just have a huge crush on it and I'd like to share the love. Minneapolis, please enjoy a screening of Love, Simon this Sunday on me.' 

Love, Simon: The hit movie Love, Simon is making waves for it's ground breaking setting about a teenager, Simon Spier who comes out as gay after high high school to his friends and family

Celebs: Aside from Matt's generosity, many other celebrities rented out movie theaters so that people could see Love, Simon for free

Buyout: Included in the list of generous stars that gave free showings were Kristen Bell, 37, and Neil Patrick Harris, 44

Free showings: Kristen, 37, bought a screening of the film in her hometown of Minneapolis and Harris bought out his hometown theater in Albuquerque, New Mexico

Meanwhile, Neil Patrick Harris, 44, and his husband David Burtka, 42, bought out NPH's hometown theater in Albuquerque, New Mexico.

'So my husband David and I enjoyed Love, Simon so much, we wanted to pay it forward,' he wrote online.

'Others are doing this and I'm so on board. So we bought out a screening at a theater in my hometown of Albuquerque, NM for this Sunday afternoon. It's free, and a great chance to see this wonderful film. Hope you can make it!'

Each of the three stars used similar branded templates to make their announcements online, indicating that it may have been done in partnership with the movie's marketing team.
item.dc:abstract: The 40-year-old White Collar star bought out the 4 p.m. screening at a Spring, Texas theater on March 25. He and his husband Simon Halls, 54, wanted people to be able to see the emotional movie about a teenager coming out as gay. Matt, who also starred in Magic Mike, came out as gay in 2012. Neil Patrick Harris and Kristen Bell have also bought out theaters so fans could see the movie.
item.dc:creator: Carly Stern
item.mi:shortTitle: Matt Bomer bought out hometown theater for people to see Love, Simon

item.title: Is THIS summer's must-have dress? Printed green midi sells out within 24 HOURS of going on sale (and you probably haven't heard of the British brand behind it)
item.description: The printed shirt dress by British newcomer Kitri comes in a vibrant shade of green - one of the season's must-have colours - and looks far more expensive than its mid-range £145 price tag.
item.content:encoded:
With summer just around the corner, shoppers are scrambling to update their wardrobes - and this pretty green dress is already proving a hit with customers. 

The printed shirt dress is a vibrant shade of green - one of the season's must-have colours - and looks far more expensive than its mid-range £145 price tag.

It is perhaps of little wonder then that it has already flown off the virtual shelves, selling out in every size within just 24 hours of its release. 

This level of frenzy is typical of the latest High Street must-haves, but the furore is all the more remarkable given the British brand behind it, Kitri, is still relatively unknown.

In demand: The printed shirt dress comes in green and looks far more expensive than its mid-range £145 price tag. It sold out within just 24 hours of being released on Saturday

Kitri, which launched in March last year, shares its name with the lead female character in the ballet Don Quixote. 

She is known for being feisty, independent and free-spirited, much like the brand’s style. 

Founder Haeni Kim was inspired to create a label through which she could design pieces that would last and that wouldn’t break the bank. 

A tuxedo jumpsuit, for example, costs only £125 and looks almost identical to one from Yves Saint Laurent that’s priced at more than £2,000. 

Summer staple: The dress, pictured, had an 800-strong waiting list before it was released

Hotly anticipated: Followers were looking forward to purchasing the 'gorgeous' frock

But it is the effortlessly chic Pleated Shirt Dress that is drawing attention this week. 

Before its release on Saturday, the Kitri team told Who What Wear that there was a list of more than 800 customers eagerly awaiting the dress' arrival.

By Sunday morning the brand's website showed the dress had sold out in sizes 6 to 16.

Instagram influencer Charlotte Groeneveld, who posts under the account The Fashion Guitar, caused a stir with her followers when she posted a photo of herself in the now sold out dress.  

Social media hit: Instagrammer Charlotte Groeneveld, who posts under The Fashion Guitar, caused a stir with followers, pictured, when she posted a photo of herself in the dress

The post has been liked more than 5,800 times and received hundreds of comments from followers praising the 'perfect look'. 

Kim said that while it was 'incredible' to see the dress sell out, the brand is not rushing to restock. 

'We hope to restock soon but we are about producing in limited quantity so we won’t be restocking a huge amount,' she said.

The frenzy comes after M&S teased the launch of its own summer wardrobe staple - a blue-and-white striped dress due to be released in May. 

The post of the frock proved so popular that it garnered more likes than a photo shared of Meghan Markle wearing an M&S jumper.

Light and fresh: The frenzy comes after M&S teased the launch of its own summer wardrobe staple - a blue-and-white striped dress, pictured, due to be released in May
item.dc:abstract: The printed shirt dress (pictured) by British newcomer Kitri is a vibrant shade of green - one of the season's must-have colours - and looks far more expensive than its mid-range £145 price tag. It had an 800-strong waiting list before it was released on Saturday (some fans' comments, bottom inset) and sold out in just 24 hours (top inset), quite a feat for a relatively unknown label.
item.dc:creator: Kerry Mcdermott
item.mi:shortTitle: Kitri green pleated dress sells out within 24 hours of being released

item.title: 'Texans at heart!' Jenna Bush Hager reveals her four-year-old daughter Mila has a tree dedicated to her in Dallas, as she shares sweet photos of her girls visiting her home state
item.description: Jenna, 36, took to Instagram on Sunday to reveal that her four-year-old daughter Mila has a tree dedicated to her at the Dallas Arboretum and Botanical Garden.
item.content:encoded:
Jenna Bush Hager may be raising her daughters in New York City, but she is also teaching them to love her home state of Texas. 

The 36-year-old Today show correspondent took to Instagram on Sunday to reveal that her four-year-old daughter Mila has a tree dedicated to her at the Dallas Arboretum and Botanical Garden.

Jenna shared an adorable photo of Mila hugging the tree, which features a plaque that reads: 'In honor of Mila Hager from her friends at the Dallas Arboretum.'

Too cute: Jenna Bush Hager, 36, took to Instagram on Sunday to share a photo of Mila hugging a tree that is dedicated to her at the Dallas Arboretum and Botanical Garden

Sister, sister: The Today show correspondent also posted a picture of Mila with her arms around her two-year-old sister, Poppy 

In the snapshot, Mila has her cheek resting on the tree's bark while she has her arms wrapped around its trunk. 

Jenna also shared a snapshot of Mila with her arms wrapped around her two-year-old sister, Poppy, during their trip to the arboretum and garden.

'Texans at [heart emoji],' Jenna captioned the two images, which prompted some fans to note that Mila is her mini-me. 

'She looks just like you!' one person wrote, while another added: 'Omg she’s your twin!'

The girls are wearing matching burnt orange dresses with white polka dots and hot pink bows in the snapshot, and someone noted that they had on Texas Longhorns colors.

Home state: Jenna (pictured with her daughters in February) grew up in Dallas and is teaching her little girls to love Texas 

The newlyweds! The night before she shared the photos from Dallas, Jenna and her husband, Henry Hager, attended her cousin Pierce Bush's wedding to Sarahbeth Melton in Colorado 

The color choice may have been intentional, as Jenna is a graduate of the University of Texas at Austin and a well-known Longhorns fan. 

The night before she shared the pictures from Dallas, Jenna and her husband, Henry Hager, were in Colorado with her family for her cousin Pierce Bush's wedding to Sarahbeth Melton. 

Pierce, 32, and his sisters Lauren Bush Lauren and Ashley Bush are the children of Neil Bush and his ex-wife, Sharon.

Jenna and her cousins are the grandchildren of former President George H.W. Bush, and her father, former President George W. Bush, was filmed tearing up the dance floor at his nephew's nuptials.

A video of the reception shows him dancing with the blushing bride while the DJ plays the '80s pop song 'You Spin Me Round.' 

Spot her! Jenna could be seen in photos and video from the day (back left)

Happy day: Jenna's father, former President George W. Bush, posed with guests at the party

Missing? It's unclear if Jenna's fraternal twin sister, Barbara Pierce Bush, and her grandmother, former First Lady Barbara Bush, attended the nuptials 

It's unclear if Jenna's fraternal sister, Barbara Bush, was at the wedding, which was held at Garden of the Gods park in Colorado Springs on Saturday.  

However, Jenna has been spending plenty of quality time with her parents as of late. Earlier this month, her mother, Laura Bush, came to New York to take Mila and Poppy to see Frozen on Broadway.

The former first daughter shared plenty of photos from the outing, including a snapshot of her mom Laura, 71, cuddling her granddaughters in the Broadway theater.

'A visit from Grammee and FROZEN on Broadway. Heaven for my babes,' Jenna captioned the images of Mila and Poppy at the show.

The musical is based on 2013 Disney film of the same name, and Jenna's daughters look like they were in awe of the entire production.

Magical day: Earlier this month, Jenna shared photos of Mila and Poppy seeing Frozen on Broadway with their grandmother Laura Bush

Frozen fun: One photo shows Jenna holding Poppy while chatting with someone on stage. Her youngest daughter was decked out in a princess costume for the show

In awe: Jenna also posted a video of Mila catching confetti in the audience

In the first photo, Laura is sitting on a bench with Poppy on her lap and Mila seated next to her.

They are all wearing their puffy winter coats, and the girls also have on plaid scarves that match the bows in their hair. 

Laura and Mila are smiling for the camera, but little Poppy has her head turned to look at something that caught her eye.

The next photo shows Jenna talking to someone on stage while holding Poppy in her arms. 

Jenna's youngest daughter looks ready for the show in a princess dress and black leather shoes. 

The proud mom also posted a video of Mila catching confetti that was falling from the ceiling while the crowd cheered during the performance.
item.dc:abstract: The 36-year-old Today show correspondent took to Instagram on Sunday to reveal that her four-year-old daughter Mila has a tree dedicated to her at the Dallas Arboretum and Botanical Garden. Jenna shared an adorable photo of Mila hugging the tree, which features a plaque that reads: 'In honor of Mila Hager from her friends at the Dallas Arboretum.'. She also posted a photo of Mila with her arms around her two-year-old sister, Poppy.
item.dc:creator: Erica Tempesta
item.mi:shortTitle: Jenna Bush Hager's daughter Mila has a tree dedicated to her in Dallas

item.title: 'I went back to work within a WEEK of giving birth': Entrepreneur, 29, reveals why nine months of maternity leave wasn't an option- and how she plans to do things differently second time round
item.description: Sydney entrepreneur, Catherine Wong, was in the middle of setting up her retail business when she got pregnant. She shared her story of returning to work within a week of giving birth.
item.content:encoded:
For most women in Australia, when they give birth, a maternity leave period of nine months is standard.

However, what do you do if you're a first-time entrepreneur or have your own very new business?

The founder of the online retailer, Black Swallow, Catherine Wong, was in the middle of setting up her business when she gave birth to her son, Lucas - meaning she felt she had to return to work within a week of having her baby.

'It was a difficult decision which I didn't take lightly,' Catherine, 29, told FEMAIL. 'But I don't regret my decision at all.'

The founder of the online retailer, Black Swallow, Catherine Wong, was in the middle of setting up her business when she gave birth to her son, Lucas (both pictured)

Because her business was in its infancy, Catherine (pictured with her partner), felt as though she had to return to work within a week of giving birth

At the time she became pregnant, Catherine, from Sydney, was setting up Black Swallow from her garage:

'I was still working as a nurse, when I became pregnant, in order to help pay the bills,' she recalled.

'I worked both jobs throughout my pregnancy up until around eight months, when I quit nursing to focus on Black Swallow full-time, transitioning from my garage to a warehouse.' 

Even though she no longer had two jobs to juggle, the 29-year-old admitted that it was hard:

'I worked right up until my due date and was back in the office within one week of giving birth,' Catherine said.

'Within a week, I was back at my desk nursing a newborn and delegating tasks to my team, who were very supportive.' 

Before she gave birth, Catherine (pictured with her family) was working as a nurse as well as setting up her business - she gave this up at eight months pregnant to focus on Black Swallow

'Within a week, I was back at my desk nursing a newborn and delegating tasks to my team, who were very supportive,' the mother-of-one (pictured with Lucas) said

Catherine's decision to return to work after giving birth wasn't purely financial, though money did have an impact:

'Quitting nursing meant that I had to pay my own maternity leave through self-employment,' she said. 

'I didn't have a choice at the time because I was responsible for staff that I had hired and the business was still new and needed me full-time.'

Mothering and working also fully took its toll on the first-time mum, who confessed she was 'always tired' and 'came close to many breakdowns' - she said she felt bad for missing things with Lucas (pictured)

'There were times when I wondered if I'd made the right decision to run my own business rather than continue to work as a nurse, which would allow me to have proper time off to simply be a mother,' Catherine (pictured) admitted to FEMAIL

Mothering and working also took its toll on the first-time mum, who confessed she was 'always tired' and 'came close to many breakdowns':

'There were times when I wondered if I'd made the right decision to run my own business rather than continue to work as a nurse, which would allow me to have proper time off to simply be a mother.'

It didn't help that at the time that Catherine was recovering from a traumatic birth - after she was induced at 38 weeks due to her baby being bigger than 95 per cent of other babies. 

'Looking back now, I was so sleep deprived, drained and often sad,' she admitted.

'I probably had undiagnosed post-natal depression which I didn't seek help for. I had a few breakdowns and lost a lot of bonding time with my son, which I won't get back.'

While the mother-of-one said she still occasionally feels 'guilty', Catherine also said she feels 'proud':

'I am due in two weeks with our second baby and the business is now at a point where I am able to take the proper time off to be the mother I wanted to be first time around,' Catherine said.

'I probably had undiagnosed post-natal depression which I didn't seek help for. I had a few breakdowns and lost a lot of bonding time with my son, which I won't get back,' Catherine said

Now, Catherine (pictured) is pregnant with her second child - and she told Daily Mail Australia that she plans to do things a little differently

Despite everything she's been through and the stresses and struggles, Catherine said she has no regrets:

'It was challenging, but I don't regret it,' she said.

'I worked hard each and every day for a year and hired an amazing team who continue to contribute to business growth. 

'The great thing is I don't need to work full-time in the office anymore. I am able to work from home while the kids nap.'
item.dc:abstract: The founder of the online retailer, Black Swallow, Catherine Wong (left with her son and right with her partner), was in the middle of setting up her business when she gave birth to her son, Lucas - meaning she felt she had to return to work within a week of having her baby. She spoke to FEMAIL about why she did it, why she had to and how she intends to do things differently second time around.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Haslett
item.mi:shortTitle: Entrepreneur on why she went back to work a week after having a baby

item.title: 'If Mirandas ruled the world, it would be considerably less f***ed up': Fans sell 'We Should All Be Mirandas' T-shirts to support Cynthia Nixon's run for governor of New York
item.description: Sex and the City superfans Lauren Garroni and Chelsea Fairless have created a line of 'Miranda Solidarity' clothing items including a 'We Should All Be Mirandas' T-shirt.
item.content:encoded:
Two Sex and the City superfans are raising money for Cynthia Nixon's gubernatorial campaign with a logo T-shirt dedicated to the actress' iconic Sex and the City character, Miranda.

Back in September, Lauren Garroni and Chelsea Fairless — the duo behind the @everyoutfitonsatc Instagram account — began selling a white logo T-shirt with the words 'We Should All Be Mirandas' emblazoned across the front.

Now, they are re-releasing the item and pledging to donate 15 per cent of all sales to Nixon's campaign for governor of New York.

Solidarity: Sex and the City superfans Lauren Garroni and Chelsea Fairless have created a line of 'Miranda Solidarity' clothing items including this 'We Should All Be Mirandas' T-shirt

Campaign: The duo first retailed the white logo t-shirt back in September 2017 but have re-released it ahead of Cynthia Nixon's run for governor of New York

Inspiration: Dior's 'We Should All Be Feminists' T-shirt inspired Garroni and Fairless

The shirt was made in the style of Dior's now-iconic 'We Should All Be Feminists' T-shirt. The Dior tee itself, which retails for $710, was inspired by Chimamanda Ngozi's book of the same name.

The idea for the Sex and the City version was born when Garroni and Fairless noticed that Miranda had started to eclipse Carrie in popularity among fans, who looking back on the show now realize Miranda was the 'sanest' of the bunch. 

Garroni and Fairless told Refinery29 that at first, they considered themselves 'Miranda apologists,' since they figured more people were 'Team Carrie.'

However, they soon realized 'there were more of us out there than we thought.'

'Although it shouldn't be surprising, as we all relate to eating cake out of the garbage. #MirandaSolidarity is for all the girls who aspire to make partner by 35 and be the first of their group to buy their own apartment on the Upper West Side,' they said. 

Team Miranda: The pair run the popular @everyoutfitonsatc Instagram account and decided to create the t-shirt when they realized people weren't as 'Team Carrie' as they thought

Goals: They have also detailed how, in hindsight, Miranda is the most identifiable character in SATC

Campaign trail: The $32 tee is on back-order, and 15 per cent of the proceeds will go towards Nixon's campaign fund

After first selling it last fall, the duo is now re-releasing the same style in the wake of Nixon's decision to run for Governor of New York.

Writing on their website that 'it's hard being a Miranda in the age of Trump and $700 feminist slogan tees,' the 'We Should All Be Miranda' t-shirt retails for $32, and 15 per cent of sales will go towards Nixon's campaign.

'But if Mirandas ruled the world, the world would be a considerably less f*cked up place. We should all be Mirandas: smart, pragmatic, ambitious and unafraid to eat cake out of the garbage,' they explained. 

On back-order, the T-shirts are expected to ship on April 11. They are also selling a baby onsie in the same style for $30, as well as 

'We desperately need representatives who want a more equal New York and refuse to fund their campaigns with corporate contributions. Also, it's [still] the Miranda thing to do,' Garroni and Fairless added.
item.dc:abstract: Sex and the City superfans Lauren Garroni and Chelsea Fairless have created a line of 'Miranda Solidarity' clothing items including a 'We Should All Be Mirandas' t-shirt. Originally released in September, the shit comes from the duo behind the popular Instagram account @everyoutfitonsatc. They are now re-releasing the t-shirt ahead of Cynthia Nixon's run for Governor of New York ,and are donating 15 per cent of sales to her campaign. Self-confessed 'Miranda apologists,' they decided to launch their range of 'Miranda Solidarity' clothing when they realized people weren't as 'Team Carrie' as they thought.
item.dc:creator: Carly Stern
item.mi:shortTitle: You can support Cynthia Nixon with a 'We Should All Be Mirandas' tee

item.title: 'Found my new hobby!' Twitter users go wild over hilarious photos of people struggling to take snapshots of mirrors - without capturing their reflections
item.description: A Twitter user known as Siv posted a series of online ads for mirrors, and every snapshot features the owner somewhere in the background.
item.content:encoded:
It turns out that selling a mirror online is no easy feat — because it is nearly impossible to snap a photo of the product without accidentally taking a selfie.

A Twitter user known as Siv posted a series of online ads for mirrors, and every snapshot features the owner somewhere in the background.

'Looking at posts from people trying to sell mirrors is my new favorite thing,' he tweeted along with the snapshots. 

Hilarious: A Twitter user known as Siv posted a series of online ads for mirrors this week, and every snapshot features the owner somewhere in the background

Hard not to smile: 'Looking at posts from people trying to sell mirrors is my new favorite thing,' he tweeted along with the snapshot

Always there: The hilarious pictures prove that is nearly impossible to snap a photo of a mirror without accidentally taking a selfie 

Missing a body: One of the funniest photos shows the reflection of a person's hand taking a photo of the ornate gold mirror

Added touch: Siv continued the thread by sharing even more images, including this one featuring a man with a professional camera 

In the first image, a guy is posed on his green carpet while snapping a photo of his black-framed mirror, and it's clear that he didn't even try to keep himself out of the frame.

Another man propped up his iPad to take a snapshot of the mirror he was selling, while one woman's online ad shows her head is peaking out of the corner of her mirror.

One of the funniest photos in the series depicts the reflection of a person's hand taking a photo of the ornate gold mirror in his upstairs hallway.

'Me when I’m going through my ugly stage but my Instagram followers haven’t seen a pic of me in a month,' someone named EJ joked while commented on the image.  

Abstract: This guy didn't think twice about sharing a photo of himself surrounded by drinks

Whoops: Not only was this guy's face in the photo, but he also captured to top of his toes 

Going for it: This guy struck a pose while taking a photo of his round mirror with a wood frame

Joining in on the fun: The post inspired other people to share similar photos of people taking pictures of mirrors in the thread

Still in the frame: One guy tried leaning over while taking a photo of his mirror 

Team work: One guy held a mirror up in front of him while someone else took the photos. Unsurprisingly, they both ended up in the picture 

Sneak attack: One person tried hiding behind the door frame while snapping a picture of a bathroom mirror 

Siv's post has received more than 472,000 'likes' and 155,000 retweets since it was shared last Wednesday, but he didn't stop there. 

The Twitter user happily added more photos to the growing thread, writing: 'This is a goldmine.' 

Some people didn't even attempt to try and hide themselves, and in one comical image a man is using a DSLR camera to take his inadvertent selfie. 

Another guy didn't seem to care at all when he shared his photo, which shows him enjoying a cocktail in the mirror's reflection. 

Dead center: A man named Robbie shared this snapshot in the thread, writing: 'Found my new hobby'

Good try: This person hid behind a bedroom door while taking this snapshot 

Always something: One woman failed to hide her feet in this photo of a silver mirror 

Lean in: It looks like this person had a tough time taking this snapshot of a full-length mirror

Stealthy: One woman tried her best to get this picture of the mirror in her entryway 

Feeling self-conscious? A man name Charles came across this online ad that features red scribble over the seller's reflection 

There were also plenty of people who tried leaning over to take their mirror photos, but their hands, arms, and portions of their bodies were still captured in the frame.

Others hid behind doors and door frames, leaving only their hands and cellphones on display in the mirrors.

Siv's posts inspired other people to start sharing similar images that they have come across — with equally hilarious results.  

While sharing a photo of an old man using a digital camera to take a photo of side mirror on his car, a Twitter user named Robbie wrote: 'Found my new hobby.'

And someone named Charles Cody posted a screenshot of an online ad for $35 mirror that features red scribble over the seller's reflection.   

'@SilviuMajor I raise your people selling mirrors. With my own people selling mirrors but self-conscious about the reflection,' he joked.
item.dc:abstract: A Twitter user known as Siv posted a series of online ads for mirrors, and every snapshot features the owner somewhere in the background. 'Looking at posts from people trying to sell mirrors is my new favorite thing,' he tweeted along with the snapshots. The post inspired others to share similar snapshots on the popular thread, which has received more than 472,000 'likes' and 155,000 retweets since last Wednesday.

item.title: The ultimate retriever! Man shares photos of his dog holding eyeglasses, a TV remote, and a bottle of KETCHUP in her mouth - and says the pup will pick up anything to get his attention
item.description: Twitter user Travis Zander, 20, of Montana shared photos of his dog Stella with unexpected objects in her mouth, explaining she tends to pick them up when she feels she's not getting enough attention.
item.content:encoded:
All dogs want is love and attention—and one canine in particular has developed an to make sure she gets the care she deserves.

Dog owner Travis Zander of Missoula, Montana, took to Twitter to share a series of photos of his one-year-old golden retriever, Stella, with various objects in her mouth, explaining that Stella has developed a habit of picking up random items as a way to catch his attention.

'My dog, Stella, is about a year and a half now and she has developed this habit where if she feels she isn't getting enough attention, she'll pick up anything in [sight] to make you tend to her,' Travis, 20, wrote.

Tactic: Twitter user Travis Zander shared a series of photos of his dog Stella, explaining she has a habit of fetching random objects to get attention

Picking up anything: The photos show the lovable dog with various objects in her mouth, including a bottle of ketchup

Thirsty: Stella, a Goldren Retriever, can be seen in one of the snaps lying on the floor with a water bottle in her mouth

Too cute: The one-year-old pet is also seen posing with a Powerade bottle and puppy eyes

Call me: Stella even stole a phone and put it in her mouth in her quest for affection

Thief: The dog can also be seen lying on the floor with a pair of reading glasses in her mouth

The dog can be seen in the snaps picking up items such as a water bottle, several cans, a sock, a bottle of ketchup, and a remote control for the TV.

Travis' original tweet has been liked 166,000 times and retweeted 68,000 times, while the follow-up messages containing more photos of Stella have garnered tens of thousands of likes too.

Some marveled at Stella's quirky habits, with one person writing: 'I'm in love with her OMG' and another declaring the golden retriever makes them 'very happy'.

One person tweeted a photo of their dog Buddy, who also appears to have a fetching habit.

Buddy can be seen in the shots with various items in his mouth, including a Kellogg's cereal box and a cardboard box meant to contain body warmers.

Bad dog: In the photo above, Stella appears to have a Coors Light can between her teeth

Back at it: The attention-seeking dog went for another can while someone petted her

Not enough: Although the cute pup seems to be getting attention, she still picked up a green container in an apparent search for more

No TV: Stella made it hard for her owner to watch television by stealing the remote

Sad puppy: She gazed forlornly with another remote in her mouth and a tennis ball to her side

Give it back: Travis shared a photo of Stella keeping his set of fishing rods hostage

Sock snatcher: Stella sat down and flashed her puppy eyes with a sock between her teeth

Snuggle: Travis is clearly close to Stella and can be seen cuddling her on a couch

Dog lover: Stella's owner, Travis (right) is seen posing with a friend sans the cute pup

Other dog lovers posted photos of their pups, explaining how their pets, too, tend to crave attention. 

One Twitter user posted a picture of their dog, a Great Dane, with the message: 'This is Lola my one and half year old Great Dane. I like to call her the velcro dog because she’s always attached to me.'

Stella is not the only pup who has captivated social media with its antics lately.

Last month, a dog named Will stared down his owner with intense puppy-dog eyes as he begged for food while sitting upright. The video of Will's behavior earned more than 1.3 million views on YouTube.

Last December, a 12-year-old golden retriever named Cash appeared to be delighted when he unwrapped a Christmas present from his owners and found a puppy inside. The moment was caught on video and promptly went viral, with thousands of viewers marveling over Cash's endearing demeanor.
item.dc:abstract: Dog owner Travis Zander of Missoula, Montana, took to Twitter to share a series of photos of his one-year-old golden retriever, Stella, with various objects in her mouth, explaining that Stella has developed a habit of picking up random items as a way to catch his attention. 'My dog, Stella, is about a year and a half now and she has developed this habit where if she feels she isn't getting enough attention, she'll pick up anything in [sight] to make you tend to her,' Travis, 20, wrote. The dog can be seen in the snaps picking up items such as a water bottle, several cans, a sock, glasses (inset) a bottle of ketchup (left), and a remote control for the TV (right).
